etymologies: mid 19th century. From French alunogène from alun + -ogène; so called because it can be converted into alum by simple chemical means

definitions: A mineral consisting of hydrated aluminium sulphate, typically occurring as masses of feathery or fibrous crystals. Compare "feather-alum", "hair-salt".

notes.text: Chemical formula: Al₂(SO₄)₃·17H₂O. Crystal system: triclinic.
